title: LCQ8: Pig farmers prosecuted for illegal discharge
secretary_name: Secretary for the Environment and Food, Mrs Lily Yam
question_text: Following is a question raised by the Hon. Albert Chan and a written reply by the Secretary for the Environment and Food, Mrs Lily Yam, in the Legislative Council meeting today(November 1): Question : I have received complaints from residents of Tin Shui Wai alleging that a nullah in the district often emits stenches caused by the discharge of untreated pig excretion into it from nearby pig farms. In this connection, will the Government inform this Council: (a) of the number of complaints about stenches from nullahs in the Tin Shui Wai district received in the last six months;

from nullahs in the Tin Shui Wai district received in the last six months; whether it has investigated the source of the stenches and the follow-up actions it has taken; (b) of the respective numbers of pig farms and pigs involved in the discharge of untreated pig excretion; and (c) of the anticipated time when the problem will be solved?
reply_text: (a) The Environmental Protection Department (EPD) has received eight complaints about stench from nullahs in the Tin Shui Wai district in the past six months.  Investigations by the Department confirmed that the stench originated from pig farms in the Tin Shui Wai district. During the same period, EPD conducted 62 surveillance operations including night-time ambushes in that area, in addition  to 71 regular visits to Tin Shui Wai farms.  As a result, three farmers in the area were caught for illegal discharges.  Prosecutions against these farmers have been initiated. EPD has informed complainants

illegal discharges.  Prosecutions against these farmers have been initiated. EPD has informed complainants of the outcome of the investigations. (b)	EPD estimates that the three farmers being prosecuted have a total of around 7,000 pigs. (c) To counter  illegal  discharge of  wastewater from pig farms, EPD will continue to take enforcement action, including regular surveillance and ambushes at night, particularly against farms with poor records. To assist pig farmers in complying with the statutory requirements, EPD will also continue to organize seminars in conjunction with organizations concerned, to give farmers technical advice on environmental protection and wastewater

continue to organize seminars in conjunction with organizations concerned, to give farmers technical advice on environmental protection and wastewater treatment. In addition, EPD and Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department regularly advises farmers to clean the livestock waste in their farm sheds more often and to feed pigs with deordorant nutrients.  These would help improve farm hygiene and reduce the smell from pig farms. The above measures would help to reduce the problem.
